Award.AwardTitle: 21st Century Antarctica - The Science and Landscape of Palmer Station
Award.AbstractNarration:
The Principal Investigator proposes to gather information about the scientific research, unique biology and
evidence of a changing climate occurring on the Antarctic Peninsula. Actin during her voyage to the Antarctic as an "expedition artist," simialr to those who were carried by early explorers, the PI will closely observe the climate, landscape, oceanography and ecology to gain first-hand knowledge about the region. She will also interact with scientists in the lab and on field studies to learn about their research and its importance to human understanding of the world and climate change. The artist will make detailed documentations of her discoveries using daily log entries, drawings, photographs, small copperplate engravings, audiofield recordings and interviews with scientists.

The Pi will use use the information gatheeed in the field as the basis for a series of cameo-glass engravings. The PI's medium is a traditional technique of carving away layers of glass to make a
relief engraving. The engravings will aim to capture the essence of the region and the research being carried out for the purpose of educating a wide public about Antarctica and the continent?s importance to global welfare. Some of the engravings will be large, wall mounted panel works and other pieces will be carved glass objects shown in wood and glass display cabinets. A catalog compiling the artist?s field studies and notes will accompany the exhibition. The Pi will also teach workshops to Seattle-area high school students. and run a similar program with youth in the summer arts program of the Service Board, a non-profit organization that mentors under-represented youth of South Seattle.

POR.DRECONTENT:
21st Century Antarctica:

The science and landscape of Palmer station

 

The major research goals of the project were to gather information about the scientific research, unique biology and rapid climate change occurring at the Western Antarctic Peninsula.  The findings and results will provide the artist with the information and materials needed to make a didactic body of artwork aimed at conveying a new understanding of contemporary Antarctica and Antarctic sciences.

 

The opportunity to work in the field provided the artist with access to information and experiences that she could not have had otherwise. The hands-on approach taught the artist not only about the enormous complexities of conducting research in Antarctica and the specifics of the Palmer LTER, but about life on station and about the local ecology and landscape.

 

The artist’s research consisted of taking photographs, sketching, keeping a daily logbook, making audio and video recordings of the surrounding environment and working side-by-side with scientists in the lab and on field excursions. The results of the research are thousands of photographs, hours of video footage, interviews and sketches. All will be used as resource materials for a body of artwork aimed at capturing the essence of the Western Antarctic peninsula and facilitating the research being carried out there.

 

Surgent is currently compiling the research that she gathered while at Palmer station and preparing for an exhibition of her art based on the project. The work that she is planning on making and showing is primarily cameo engraved glass wall pieces (her chosen medium), carved glass sculpture and photographs. The exhibition of Surgent’s work will be held at Traver Gallery in Seattle, WA in October 2014. Accompanying the exhibition will be a short documentary film using footage shot on station and a 35-page exhibition catalogue.
